anatomical location body part affected: Pelvic floor/bladder detrusor muscle and urinary sphincter
description: Uncontrolled leakage of urine occurs in up to 35% of cases after transurethral (laparoscopic) resection or radical retropubic excision of the prostate gland.(1,28) Post-prostatectomy  urinary incontinence (PUI) usually is evident immediately after radical surgery, often continuing for several weeks or months and having a significant impact on quality of life(28)

The supportive function of the pelvic diaphragm, which consists of the levator ani (pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus) and ischiococcygeus muscles, may become compromised after prostatectomy and thereby contribute to urinary incontinence(4)
Fairly strong evidence indicates that pelvic floor muscle exercise training can improve continence in most cases of mild to moderate PUI(4)

In addition to pelvic floor exercises (with or without biofeedback), therapeutic interventions for PUI may involve electrical stimulation, external compression devices (e.g., penile clamp), extracorporeal magnetic innervation, and behavioral support(6)

ICD-10 codes.N39.4: other specified urinary incontinence (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

Self-Care G-code set.G8987: Self-care  functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Self-Care G-code set.G8988: Self-care  functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Self-Care G-code set.G8989: Self-care  functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement for therapy has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Male patient with a history of prostatectomy and urinary incontinence

Reported PUI may range from momentary leakage during activities that increase intraabdominal pressure, such as in coughing, laughing, squatting, or performing the Valsalva maneuver (i.e., transient stress incontinence), to continuous leakage without stress
A self-report  instrument such as the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire Short-Form  (ICIQ-SF)  may help identify the severity of current problems(5)
To prevent soiling, patients typically wear various types of disposable absorbent pads in mild cases of PUI, or urinary sheath drainage systems in severe cases
Urinary symptoms typically vary over time. It has been noted that for many men urinary control is regained at approximately 100 days into recovery(43) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Confirm and follow physician’s orders/restrictions, especially with regard to exercise (e.g., lifting or straining)

Practitioners performing pelvic floor muscle examinations and designing treatment regimens must ensure that they have proper training and stay within the boundaries of the scope of practice allowed by their license

Provide a thorough explanation of the reason for pelvic floor muscle testing and give patient an opportunity to refuse digital rectal exam; obtain signed consent to digital pelvic floor muscle examination
Individual screening and assessment are necessary for exercise prescription
Reassure patient that he may use the toilet as needed, prior to and during the exam
Advise patient on the possibility of stress incontinence during the exam

causes: Impaired function of the external sphincter is considered to be the major reason for incontinence after radicalprostatectomy. Detrusor overactivity and reduced bladder compliance are also causative factors(41)
Although PUI likely results from surgical trauma or damage, the exact mechanism may differ from case to case. Inaddition, urinary incontinence prior to surgery may complicate the etiology of PUI(1)
Damage to or removal of all or part of the internal urinary sphincter (segment above the genitourinary diaphragm) due toradical prostatectomy

Urodynamic and cystoscopic studies have identified two main reasons for PUI(2,3,7)–Injury to the distal (external) urinary rhabdosphincter–The functional length and control of the internal sphincteric segment remaining after surgery (particularly in cases withpersistent incontinence after functional recovery of the external voluntary sphincter)
Pre-existing  detrusor muscle spasms (unstable bladder contractions), especially in the neck of bladder, can contribute tourge PUI in some cases
Pelvic floor weakness (note: the external sphincter is contained within the pelvic floor muscles)
pathogenesis ,,: Continence and voluntary urination involve a balance between contraction of the internal and external urethral sphinctersas the bladder fills and contraction of the detrusor (the intrinsic muscle of the urinary bladder) during micturition.Incontinence can result from poor detrusor-sphincter  coordination

The bladder neck and urethra are supported by the pelvic diaphragm. With increased abdominal pressure, weakness orunresponsiveness of the pelvic floor muscles may allow these structures to move downward into the position normal forurination, leading to stress incontinence

In men, the multilayered fibers of the detrusor muscle arise partly from the prostate and its capsule. Disruption of thesefibers may cause the detrusor muscle instability associated with urge incontinence
risk factors: increased risk of pui is: radical prostatectomy (increases risk of persistent PUI)(1)

overall contraindications precautions: If metastatic cancer is present, request specific precautions from patient’s oncologist
Allow patient to be accompanied by a caregiver or partner during the exam and treatment

Patients receiving chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy for cancer may experience overwhelming fatigue associated with functional decline (see  Clinical Review…Cancer-Related  Fatigue ; Item Number: T708776)
Ensure that the patient has received medical clearance for exercise therapy. Exercise may be contraindicated in patients with metastasis to bone
Confirm that the patient does not have unstable cardiac disease, acute infection, or any other acute medical condition that would contraindicate exercise

Guidelines for modifying physical activity during and after cancer treatment include the following:(10) When severe anemia is present, postpone exercise Advise patient with immunosuppression not to exercise in public recreational centers until white cell count has normalized When fatigue is severe, limit exercise to “as tolerated,” such as gentle stretching as able and indicated During radiation treatment, do not expose skin to chlorinated pools When urinary catheter is in place, avoid immersion in pools When patient presents with peripheral neuropathy, modify treatment plan to manage altered balance and coordination

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the date of prostate surgery. Did the patient experience urinary incontinence before prostatectomy or only afterwards? How have symptoms of PUI changed since surgery?  -Describe the surgical procedure performed -Surgical intervention with transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) carries a significant risk of incontinence compared to laser prostatectomy(35) -Robotic-assisted  laparoscopic prostatectomy (RALP) is reported to facilitate earlier return to physical activity compared to open retropubic prostatectomy (ORP)(36) -Did the patient have radiation therapy or brachytherapy before prostatectomy?

course of treatment.medical management: Has the patient been asked to keep a bladder diary to record the pattern of voiding, noting times and the amounts of urine produced? What conservative or behavioral therapies for incontinence have been tried? Document whether cancer treatment is continuing and, if so, the type of treatment
surgical management: Surgical management:  Surgical options for PUI persisting longer than 12 months despite conservative therapy include
the artificial urinary sphincter (AUS800)  and male sling devices(11)
course of treatment.medications: Treatment with duloxetine (Cymbalta) in combination with physiotherapy may improve continence in some patients(6)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following
Stress test  the patient relaxes in supine and/or standing, then coughs vigorously as the clinician checks for loss of urine
Urinalysis  for evidence of infection, stones, or other contributing causes
Ultrasound  to visualize anatomy of the pubic area, kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra
Cystoscopy  use of fiber optics to see inside the urethra and bladder
Urodynamics  measurement of pressure in the bladder and the flow of urine
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of Kegel exercises, an electrical stimulator, or magnets at home; document any use of alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for orthopedic or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors related to stress incontinence
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling), if applicable
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms of incontinence at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document usual number of episodes of nocturnal incontinence (enuresis)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document whether patient uses supplemental oxygen Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including neurological diseases, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms that should be considered during therapy

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: PUI/confirmation of significant urine leakage with 24-hour  Pad Test; diminished quality of life; trial of conservative therapy is indicated by symptoms
assessment plan of care.rule out: Neurogenic bladder disease (e.g., spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, stroke), diabetes; urinary tract infection
prognosis: Prognosis is favorable during the first 6 to 12 months in mild cases of PUI(6)

The percentage of patients with PUI who do not achieve continence during the first year after transurethral resection or simple open prostatectomy ranges from 7% to 35%, whether medically treated or not.(1,16,17,28) Complications such as severe damage to the urinary sphincter or bladder dysfunction related to surgery worsen the prognosis(17)
At 5-year  follow-up,  14% of 1,288 men in the United States who underwent radical prostatectomyreported frequent urinary leakage or no urinary control after diagnosis of PUI(18)
Sparing of bladder neck function during surgery may improve recovery of continence at 1 month, based on a prospective multicenter study of 2,408 men in Italy(19)

In a randomized controlled trial (RCT) conducted in Canada, authors found no significant difference in return to continence at 8, 28, or 52 weeks after radical prostatectomy between groups randomized to once-a-week  postoperative pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) for 4 weeks (n = 106) or supportive telephone contact by a urology nurse (n = 99)(20)

In a cohort (N = 1,655) of the Prostate Cancer Outcomes Study in the United States, investigators observed no significant differences in rates of erectile dysfunction or bowel urgency at 15-year  follow-up between the group (n = 1,164) that had prostatectomy versus the group (n = 491) that underwent radiotherapy(31)

In a multicenter longitudinal study (N = 350) in Germany, investigators found no significant difference in urinary continence at 3-month  follow-up  between the group (n = 166) that had endoscopic radical prostatectomy versus the group (n = 184) that underwent open retropubic prostatectomy(32)

A prediction model to help counsel post-radical  prostatectomy patients about functional recovery, developed from data from 2,162 patients who reported urinary and erectile dysfunction, suggests that there is an opportunity for early identification of patients likely to have long-term  urinary dysfunction based on their current function(42) –Most published prediction models for urinary recovery tend to focus on preoperative function and are intended to be used as tools to aid initial treatment decision making(42) –In a study conducted in the United States, logistic regression models predicting function at 1 or 2 years post radical prostatectomy were developed on the basis of function at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months post prostatectomy(42) -A patient’s self-reported  urinary and erectile function in the first months after radical prostatectomy is an extremely strong predictor of whether a patient will eventually regain continence -Other predictors, including age, stage, grade, prostate-specific  antigen (PSA) levels, nerve sparing status, and baseline functional scores, do not add predictive value
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Occupational therapist for disability in ADLs Acupuncturist for cancer-related  pain and fatigue Behavioral psychologist for behavioral therapy Support group
other considerations: Authors of a literature review of 12 studies indicate that better education on self-management  of PUI is needed(33)

The approach to both long-term  and short-term  supportive care post prostatectomy is often limited to professional counseling, which typically involves a discussion between patient and healthcare provider about the disease and treatment. Participants in a study investigating a strategy for meeting men’s informational needs after radical prostatectomy indicated that the counseling did little to prepare them for the day to day management of urinary and/or erectile problems(43) –Based on a study conducted in the United States that involved 22 patients who had had radical prostatectomy within the prior 12 months –Participants all experienced urinary and erectile side effects that they considered debilitating –Needs changed over time after surgery, causing the patients to periodically re-evaluate  how to deal with day to day management of urinary and erectile dysfunction –The authors of the study identified a need for establishment of a standard of care that includes providing information relevant to non-invasive  ways of dealing with urinary and erectile symptoms post radical prostatectomy  -Information should include information about products and supplies to manage urinary incontinence and instructions on how they can be used in daily management
Patients who also have fecal leakage require an additional workup, assessment, and treatment plan (see Clinical Review… Incontinence, Fecal, in Adults ; Item Number: T708638)

Placement of a transobturator urethral sling is reported to provide excellent continence outcomes in patients with postprostatectomy incontinence, except in patients who have a history of previous pelvic irradiation(37)

Preoperative selection of “ideal” patients for undergoing male sling placement for postprostatectomy incontinence can improve favorable outcomes(38) –In a study conducted in the United States, ideal patients for this procedure were identified as patients with mild to moderate incontinence, ability to volitionally contract the external urinary sphincter, no history of pelvic radiation or cryotherapy, no history of previous anti-incontinence surgical procedures, the ability to generate volitional detrusor contraction, and a post void residual volume < 100 ml
treatment summary: PFMT, also known as Kegel exercises, is generally recognized as safe and effective for improving mild to moderate cases of urinary incontinence during the first 6 months after prostatectomy based on RCTs(4,6,16,17,21,22,23,27) –Ninety five percent of patients who started PFMT early (after removal of the catheter or before hospital discharge) were continent at 6 months compared to 65% of patients in the control group, who did not receive postoperative PFMT(16) –In an RCT (N = 206) conducted in Canada, investigators found that verbal and written instruction for PFMT at home with telephone support was as effective as therapist-directed PFMT with biofeedback (once per week, 4 weeks).(17) No differences were found in the percentage of patients continent at 8 weeks (23% of home controls vs. 20% of treatment group), 28 weeks (50% vs. 47%), or 52 weeks (64% and 60%). The results of this study suggest that more intensive PFMT and follow-up  testing should accompany a primarily home-based  program(17) –Support group attendance may improve outcomes after PFMT, based on a small RCT (N = 29) in the United States.(21) The authors found self-assessed urinary continence and quality of life were higher in the group that attended 6 biweekly support group meetings after PFMT compared to the control group, which was assigned to a home program without support after PFMT(21) –Instruction of pelvic floor exercises with hands-on  cueing followed by unsupervised training may be as effective as PFMT with biofeedback. Intensive verbal instruction with examiner feedback on pelvic floor performance administered before PFMT was associated with a similar continence rate at 6 months after prostatectomy as PFMT with ongoing conventional biofeedback.(22) This study did not include a no-treatment  control group –In contrast to the above studies, 2 parallel RCTs in the United Kingdom found that the rate of continuing PUI at 12 months was not significantly different between the 2 intervention groups that received 4 sessions of PFMT over a period of 3 months and the 2 control groups that received standard care or lifestyle advice only(23) –Example of verbal instructions for pelvic-floor  muscle training(20) -“If you can stop the flow of urine in midstream, you are squeezing the correct muscles. Imagine you are trying to stop yourself from passing gas. Squeeze the muscle around the rectum. The rectal muscle should move, but the buttocks, thighs, and stomach should stay relaxed. These (other) muscles should not move at all. You should feel and see the base of your penis twitch and contract inwards. Squeeze firmly (and hold) for 5 to 10 seconds. Relax for 10 to 20 seconds. Repeat the contractions 12 to 20 times. Perform the exercises 3 times a day”

Functional electrical stimulation (FES) –Investigators compared PFMT with FES using anal surface electrodes (27 Hz, biphasic, 1-sec  bursts, 5-sec  pulse width, 2-sec  pulse trains, intensity controlled by patient from 10% to 100%) to PFMT alone and to PFMT in conjunction with biofeedback in an RCT (N = 139) in Germany.(24) FES was performed for 15 minutes twice daily and commenced at catheter removal. No significant differences in results of the continence rate (24-hour  Pad Test) were found among the 3 groups at 3 and 12 months follow-up,  suggesting that FES is not cost-effective.(24) This RCT did not include a no-treatment  control group –In an RCT (N = 60) in Italy, the authors observed that twice weekly FES sessions (anal surface electrode, pulsed at 30 Hz for 10 min and then at 50 Hz for 10 min; 300 microsecond pulse duration, max intensity 24 mA) preceded by biofeedback (15 min) from 1 to 7 weeks post prostatectomy significantly increased the percentage of patients achieving continence (24-hourPad  Test) at 4 weeks and 6 months compared to the control group, which received standard instructions for home PFMT.(25) Unfortunately, the independent effect of FES was not determined because it was combined with biofeedback

Extracorporeal magnetic innervation (ExMI) –In a small RCT (N = 36) in Japan, investigators compared patients receiving FES (n = 12) or ExMI (n = 12) to controls (n = 12) assigned to PFMT at home after receiving verbal instruction with digital rectal feedback.(26) ExMI consisted of twice weekly sessions for 2 months using a pulse field of 10 Hz intermittently for 10 minutes followed by 50 Hz intermittently for 10 minutes at the highest tolerated intensity. Patients sat on a magnetic coil with the perineum positioned over the center of the coil. FES was applied with an anal electrode at pulses of 20-Hz  square waves with a 300-microsec  pulse duration for 15 minutes twice daily for 1 month. Continence was assessed by 24-h pad weights. ExMI significantly reduced incontinence at 2 months after surgery compared to PFMT, while 24-h pad weights at 1 and 2 months were not significantly different between FES and ExMI. Interestingly, continence was similar among the 3 groups at 6 months post-surgery.  The authors suggested that FES and ExMI offer earlier recovery for PUI compared to home-based  PFMT(26) –In a small study (N = 40) in Italy comparing PFMT using FES (n = 18) to ExMI (n = 22) for treating PUI, authors found no significant difference in continence between groups at 6-week  follow-up.  Of note, leakage was reduced after ExMI in 6 patients who had not responded to FES(34)

Behavioral therapy (PFMT plus counseling on bladder control strategies) –Behavioral therapy alone was as effective as behavioral therapy plus FES and biofeedback for decreasing episodes of incontinence in men with PUI persisting more than 1 year(27) -Based on an RCT in the United States with 208 community-dwelling  men (51 to 81 years of age) with incontinence 1 to 17 years after radical prostatectomy -Participants were randomly assigned to 1 of 3 groups -Behavioral therapy-only  (4 structured visits approximately 2 weeks apart and home exercises 3 times daily) -Behavioral therapy plus in-office  biofeedback using electromyography (EMG) plus daily FES (20 Hz, up to 100 mA) -Delayed treatment (control group) -After 8 weeks of treatment, the reduction in mean incontinence episodes per week was not significantly different between the 2 behavioral therapy groups, while both were significantly reduced more than the controls -Fifty-five  percent reduction in the behavioral therapy-only  group -Fifty-one  percent reduction in the behavioral therapy plus biofeedback and FES group -Twenty-four  percent reduction in control group –Results of a 2013 systematic review indicate that psychoeducational interventions such as education and counseling intended to inform postprostatectomy patients and their caregivers about their disease and their treatment positively influence their disease perception, self-management,  and coping(39) -Four of eight studies included specifically addressed urinary incontinence -Significant effects of psychoeducational interventions were found in some vulnerable groups but not others -Men with preexisting low level of depression were reported to respond positively, but not men with higher levels of depression, thought to be related to their ability to focus on problem-solving

Authors of a 2016 systematic review with meta-analysis  found biofeedback training to be useful for pelvic floor muscle training in order to reduce urinary incontinence when compared to PFMT alone(44) –Thirteen RCTs used in this meta-analysis  (N = 1108) with patients who had undergone radical prostatectomy

Authors of a 2017 study conducted in Australia suggest that individuals who have had a prostatectomy may benefit from a general exercise program in order to minimize the severity of UI. However, further RCTs are warranted to determine the effects of exercise in this population group(45) .
